name: Computer Graphics
timeline: 1963: Ivan Sutherland develops Sketchpad, a pioneering interactive graphical system.
1971: Henri Gouraud introduces Gouraud shading for smooth surfaces.
1974: Edwin Catmull develops Z-buffering for visible surface determination.
1977: James Blinn introduces environment mapping and bump mapping.
1980s: Development of ray tracing and radiosity algorithms for global illumination.
1990s: Emergence of OpenGL and DirectX for real-time 3D graphics.
2000s: Rise of programmable shaders and GPU acceleration.
2010s: Advancements in physically based rendering and real-time global illumination.
2020s: Integration of AI/ML into graphics for content generation and rendering.

subfields.name: Real-time Rendering
keyProblems: Achieving high frame rates for complex scenes
Efficiently managing memory for large assets
timeline: 1990s: Fixed-function pipeline GPUs emerge.
2001: NVIDIA introduces the GeForce 3, featuring programmable shaders.
2006: DirectX 10 and Shader Model 4.0 bring unified shader architecture.
2014: Epic Games releases Unreal Engine 4 with physically based rendering.
2016: Vulkan API released, offering low-overhead GPU access.
2018: NVIDIA introduces real-time ray tracing with RTX GPUs.
advancements: Hardware-accelerated ray tracing in real-time
Neural rendering for scene representation
Variable Rate Shading (VRS)
Mesh Shaders for more flexible geometry processing
DirectStorage for faster asset loading
Global Illumination via Lumen and similar technologies
AI-powered upscaling techniques (DLSS, FSR)
